Keyed Layouts

@docs row, column, wrappedRow, wrappedColumn, grid, namedGrid

values.type: style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List ( String, Element.Element style variation msg ) -> Element.Element style variation msg

name: Element
comment:
# Capture Layout in your View

Think of `Elements` as `Html` with layout!

By building your view with `Elements`, you have a single place to go to adjust or add to your layout, which is great because that's usually what you're doing in your view!


## Rendering

@docs layout, viewport


## Basic Elements

@docs Element, Attribute

@docs empty, text, el, html, map, when, whenJust


# Layout

A layout element will explicitly define how it's children are layed out.

Make sure to check out the Style Element specific attributes in `Element.Attributes` as they will help out when doing layout!


## Linear Layouts

@docs row, column, wrappedRow, wrappedColumn


## Text Layout

@docs textLayout, paragraph


## Grid Layout

@docs table, Grid, NamedGrid, grid, namedGrid, OnGrid, NamedOnGrid, area, named, span, spanAll


## Convenience Elements

@docs full, spacer, hairline, link, image, circle, break


## Positioning

It can be useful to position something near another element.

In CSS terms, this positions children using 'position:absolute'. So, to position three boxes below a container, we could do the following:

     el MyStyle [ width (px 200), height (px 200) ] empty
        |> below
            [ el Box [ width (px 40), height (px 40) ] empty
            -- below on the right
            , el Box [ alignRight, width (px 40), height (px 40) ] empty
            -- below and centered
            , el Box [ center, width (px 40), height (px 40) ] empty
            ]

@docs below, above, onRight, onLeft, within, screen


## Responsive

Since this library moves all layout and positioning logic to the view instead of the stylesheet, it doesn't make a ton of sense to support media queries in the stylesheet.

Instead, responsiveness is controlled directly in the view.

Here's how it's done:

1.  Set up a subscription to `Window.resizes` from the `Window` package.
2.  Use the `Element.classifyDevice` function which will convert `Window.width` and `Window.height` into a `Device` record, which you should store in your model.
3.  Use the `Device` record in your view to specify how your page changes with window size.
4.  If things get crazy, use the `responsive` function to map one range to another.

Check out the [elm.style website source](https://github.com/mdgriffith/elm.style) for a real example.

@docs Device, classifyDevice, responsive


## Text Markup

These elements are useful for quick text markup.

@docs bold, italic, strike, underline, sub, super


## Semantic Markup

This library made the opinionated choice to make layout a first class concern of your `view` function.

However it's still very useful to have semantic markup in places. The following nodes can be used to annotate your layouts.

So, if we wanted to make a standard element be rendered as a `section` node, we could do the following

    -- Regular element
    el MyStyle [] (text "Hello World!")

    -- Same element annotated as a `section`
    section <| el MyStyle [] (text "Hello World!")

@docs node, button, header, section, nav, article, aside, canvas, iframe, audio, video


## Form Elements

Some convient elements for working with forms.

@docs form, checkbox, label, labelBelow, inputText, textArea, radio, select, option, Option


## Advanced Rendering

@docs toHtml, embedStylesheet


### Deprecated

@docs root, embed, render

aliases.name: Device
aliases.type: { width : Int , height : Int , phone : Bool , tablet : Bool , desktop : Bool , bigDesktop : Bool , portrait : Bool }

aliases.name: Element
aliases.comment:
You can think of an `Element` as `Html` with built-in layout.

It has one `style` identifier, which you can think of as a CSS class.

It can also have style `variations`, which are covered in the `Style` module.

aliases.name: Grid
aliases.type: { rows : List Style.Internal.Model.Length , columns : List Style.Internal.Model.Length }

aliases.name: NamedGrid
aliases.type: { rows : List ( Style.Internal.Model.Length , List Style.Internal.Model.NamedGridPosition ) , columns : List Style.Internal.Model.Length }

values.name: above
values.type: List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: area
values.comment: Specify a specific position on a normal `grid`.
values.type: Element.GridPosition -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.OnGrid (Element.Element style variation msg)

values.name: article
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: aside
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: audio
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: below
values.type: List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: break
values.comment:
Make a line-break.

You probably want to use `paragraph` instead. This is only for adjusting where a sentance should break, not for formating paragraphs.

values.name: button
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: canvas
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: checkbox
values.comment: An automatically labeled checkbox.
values.type: Bool -> style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: circle
values.comment:
A simple circle. Provide the radius it should have.

Automatically sets the propery width, height, and corner rounded.
values.type: Float -> style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: classifyDevice
values.comment: Takes in a Window.Size and returns a device profile which can be used for responsiveness.

values.name: column
values.type: style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: el
values.comment:
The most basic element.

You need to specify a style, a list of attributes, and a single child.

    -- an element with the style `MyStyle`, that is aligned left, and has one child.
    el MyStyle [ alignLeft ] (text "Hello World!")

`el` can only have one child because in order to have multiple children, we need to specify how the layout would work.
values.type: style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: embed
values.comment: DEPRECATED, will be removed in the next major version. Use `embedStylesheet` instead.

values.name: embedStylesheet
values.comment: Embed a stylesheet.

values.name: form
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: full
values.comment:
A `full` element will ignore the spacing set for it by the parent, and also grow to cover the parent's padding.

This is mostly useful in text layouts.
values.type: style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: grid
values.comment:
An interface to css grid. Here's a basic example:

    grid MyGridStyle
        { columns = [ px 100, px 100, px 100, px 100 ]
        , rows =
            [ px 100
            , px 100
            , px 100
            , px 100
            ]
        }
        []
        [ area
            { start = ( 0, 0 )
            , width = 1
            , height = 1
            }
            (el Box [] (text "box"))
        , area
            { start = ( 1, 1 )
            , width = 1
            , height = 2
            }
            (el Box [] (text "box"))
        ]
values.type: style -> Element.Grid -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List (Element.OnGrid (Element.Element style variation msg)) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: hairline
values.comment:
Creates a 1 px tall horizontal line.

If you want a horizontal rule that is something more specific, craft it with `el`!

values.name: header
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: html
values.comment:
For when you want to embed `Html`.

If you're using this library, I'd encourage you to try to solve your problem without using this escape hatch.

Usage of this function makes the most sense when you're dealing with `Html` from another module or package.
values.type: Html.Html msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: iframe
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: image
values.comment: A convenience node for images. Accepts an image src as the first argument.
values.type: String -> style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: inputText
values.comment:
Text input

    label LabelStyle [] (text "check this out") <|
        inputText Style [] "The Value!"
values.type: style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> String -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: label
values.comment:
For input elements that are not automatically labeled (checkbox, radio), this will attach a label above the element.

    label Label [] (text "check this out") <|
        inputText Style [] "The Value!"
values.type: style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: labelBelow
values.comment: Same as `label`, but places the label below the input field.
values.type: style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: layout
values.comment: Embeds the stylesheet and renders the `Element`'s into `Html`.
values.type: Style.StyleSheet style variation -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Html.Html msg

values.name: link
values.comment:
Turn an element into a link.

    link "http://zombo.com"
        <| el MyStyle (text "Welcome to Zombocom")

Changes an element's node to `<a>` and sets the href. `rel` properties are set to `noopener` and `noreferrer`.
values.type: String -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: map
values.comment:
Change the msg that an Element is sending.

An analog of `Html.map`.
values.type: (a -> msg) -> Element.Element style variation a -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: named
values.comment: Specify a named postion on a `namedGrid`.
values.type: String -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.NamedOnGrid (Element.Element style variation msg)

values.name: namedGrid
values.comment:
With a named grid, you can name areas within the grid and use that name to place an element.

Here's an example:

    namedGrid MyGridStyle
        { columns = [ px 200, px 200, px 200, fill 1 ]
        , rows =
            [ px 200 => [ spanAll "header" ]
            , px 200 => [ span 3 "content", span 1 "sidebar" ]
            , px 200 => [ span 3 "content", span 1 "sidebar" ]
            , px 200 => [ spanAll "footer" ]
            ]
        }
        []
        [ named "header"
            (el Box [] (text "box"))
        , named "sidebar"
            (el Box [] (text "box"))
        ]

**note:** this example uses rocket(`=>`) as a synonym for creating a tuple. For more, check out the [rocket update](https://github.com/NoRedInk/rocket-update) package!
values.type: style -> Element.NamedGrid -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List (Element.NamedOnGrid (Element.Element style variation msg)) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: nav
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: node
values.type: String -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: onLeft
values.type: List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: onRight
values.type: List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: option
values.comment: Create an Option. Can only be used with `radio` and `select`.
values.type: String -> Bool -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Option style variation msg

values.name: paragraph
values.comment:
Paragraph is actually a layout if you can believe it!

This is the same as a textLayout, except all of the children are set to `display:inline`.

Because all the children are inline, they will not respect and width or height set on them.
values.type: style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: radio
values.comment:
Create a list of labeled radio button.

This implies a column layout.

    radio "lunch" None []
        [ option "burrito" True (text "A Burrito!")
        , option "taco" False (text "A Taco!")
        ]
values.type: String -> style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List (Element.Option style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: render
values.comment: DEPRECATED, will be removed in the next major version. Use `toHtml` instead.
values.type: Style.StyleSheet style variation -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Html.Html msg

values.name: responsive
values.comment:
Define two ranges that should linearly match up with each other.

Provide a value for the first and receive the calculated value for the second.

    fontsize =
        responsive device.width ( 600, 1200 ) ( 16, 20 )

When the device width is between 600 and 1200, set the font-size between 16 and 20 using a linear scale.
values.type: Float -> ( Float, Float ) -> ( Float, Float ) -> Float

values.name: root
values.comment: DEPRECATED, will be removed in the next major version. Use `layout` instead.
values.type: Style.StyleSheet style variation -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Html.Html msg

values.name: row
values.type: style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: screen
values.comment:
Position an element relative to the window.

Essentially the same as `display: fixed`
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: section
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: select
values.comment:
A standard html dropdown set of options.

    select "favorite-animal" MySelectionStyle []
        [ option "manatee" False (text "Manatees are pretty cool")
        , option "pangolin" False (text "But so are pangolins")
        , option "bee" True (text "Bees")
        ]
values.type: String -> style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List (Element.Option style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: spacer
values.comment:
An element for adding additional spacing. The `Float` is the multiple that should be used of the spacing that's being set by the parent.

So, if the parent element is a `column` that set spacing to `5`, and this spacer was a `2`. Then it would be a 10 pixel spacer.

values.name: span
values.comment: Used to define named areas in a `namedGrid`.

values.name: spanAll
values.comment: Used to define named areas in a `namedGrid`.

values.name: table
values.comment: A table is a special grid
values.type: style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List (List (Element.Element style variation msg)) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: textArea
values.type: style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> String -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: textLayout
values.comment:
A text layout.

Children that are aligned left or right will be floated left or right. Everything else if arranged in the standard 'block' layout of css, meaning a column flowing down.
values.type: style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: toHtml
values.comment: Renders `Element`'s into `Html`, but does not embed a stylesheet.
values.type: Style.StyleSheet style variation -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Html.Html msg

values.name: video
values.type: Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: viewport
values.comment: Same as `layout`, but the height and width of the site is set to the height and width of the screen.
values.type: Style.StyleSheet style variation -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Html.Html msg

values.name: when
values.comment:
A helper function. This:

    when (x == 5) (text "yay, it's 5")

is sugar for

    if (x == 5) then
        text "yay, it's 5"
    else
        empty
values.type: Bool -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: whenJust
values.comment:
Another helper function that defaults to `empty`

    whenJust (Just ("Hi!")) text

is sugar for

    case maybe of
        Nothing ->
            empty
        Just x ->
            text x
values.type: Maybe.Maybe a -> (a -> Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: within
values.type: List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: wrappedColumn
values.type: style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

values.name: wrappedRow
values.type: style -> List (Element.Attribute variation msg) -> List (Element.Element style variation msg) -> Element.Element style variation msg

name: Style.Font

values.name: alignLeft
values.comment: Align the font to the left.

values.name: alignRight
values.comment: Align the font to the right.

values.name: center
values.comment: Align font center.

values.name: letterSpacing
values.comment: In `px`.

values.name: lineHeight
values.comment: Given as a ratio of the `Font.size`.

values.name: size
values.comment: Font size specified in `px`

values.name: wordSpacing
values.comment: In `px`.

values.name: wrap
values.comment: Renders as "white-space:normal", which is the standard wrapping behavior you're probably used to.

name: Style.Color
comment:
Set Colors for your style.

Meant to be imported as

    import Style.Color as Color

@docs text, background, border, cursor, decoration, selection, placeholder

values.name: decoration
values.comment: Text decoration color.

values.name: placeholder
values.comment: The color of the input `placeholder` element.

name: Element.Attributes

values.name: accept
values.comment:
List of types the server accepts, typically a file type.
For `form` and `input`.

values.name: acceptCharset
values.comment: List of supported charsets in a `form`.

values.name: accesskey
values.comment: Defines a keyboard shortcut to activate or add focus to the element.

values.name: action
values.comment: The URI of a program that processes the information submitted via a `form`.

values.name: align
values.comment:
Specifies the horizontal alignment of a `caption`, `col`, `colgroup`,
`hr`, `iframe`, `img`, `table`, `tbody`, `td`, `tfoot`, `th`, `thead`, or
`tr`.

values.name: alt
values.comment:
Alternative text in case an image can't be displayed. Works with `img`,
`area`, and `input`.

values.name: async
values.comment: Indicates that the `script` should be executed asynchronously.

values.name: attribute
values.comment:
Create *attributes*, like saying `domNode.setAttribute('class', 'greeting')`
in JavaScript.

    class : String -> Attribute variation msg
    class =
        Html.Attributes.class

Read more about the difference between properties and attributes [here].

[here]: https://github.com/elm-lang/html/blob/master/properties-vs-attributes.md

values.name: autocomplete
values.comment:
Indicates whether a `form` or an `input` can have their values automatically
completed by the browser.

values.name: autofocus
values.comment:
The element should be automatically focused after the page loaded.
For `button`, `input`, `keygen`, `select`, and `textarea`.

values.name: autoplay
values.comment: The `audio` or `video` should play as soon as possible.

values.name: challenge
values.comment: A challenge string that is submitted along with the public key in a `keygen`.

values.name: charset
values.comment:
Declares the character encoding of the page or script. Common values include:

  - UTF-8 - Character encoding for Unicode
  - ISO-8859-1 - Character encoding for the Latin alphabet

For `meta` and `script`.

values.name: checked
values.comment: Indicates whether an `input` of type checkbox is checked.

values.name: cite
values.comment:
Contains a URI which points to the source of the quote or change in a
`blockquote`, `del`, `ins`, or `q`.

values.name: class
values.comment: Often used with CSS to style elements with common properties.

values.name: classList
values.comment:
This function makes it easier to build a space-separated class attribute.
Each class can easily be added and removed depending on the boolean value it
is paired with. For example, maybe we want a way to view notices:

    viewNotice : Notice -> Html msg
    viewNotice notice =
        div
            [ classList
                [ ( "notice", True )
                , ( "notice-important", notice.isImportant )
                , ( "notice-seen", notice.isSeen )
                ]
            ]
            [ text notice.content ]
values.type: List ( String, Bool ) -> Element.Internal.Model.Attribute variation msg

values.name: clip
values.comment: Clip content that overflows.

values.name: cols
values.comment: Defines the number of columns in a `textarea`.

values.name: colspan
values.comment:
The colspan attribute defines the number of columns a cell should span.
For `td` and `th`.

values.name: content
values.comment:
A value associated with http-equiv or name depending on the context. For
`meta`.

values.name: contenteditable
values.comment: Indicates whether the element's content is editable.

values.name: contextmenu
values.comment:
Defines the ID of a `menu` element which will serve as the element's
context menu.

values.name: controls
values.comment:
Indicates whether the browser should show playback controls for the `audio`
or `video`.

values.name: coords
values.comment:
A set of values specifying the coordinates of the hot-spot region in an
`area`. Needs to be paired with a `shape` attribute to be meaningful.

values.name: datetime
values.comment:
Indicates the date and time associated with the element.
For `del`, `ins`, `time`.

values.name: default
values.comment:
Indicates that the `track` should be enabled unless the user's preferences
indicate something different.

values.name: defaultValue
values.comment:
Defines an initial value which will be displayed in an `input` when that
`input` is added to the DOM. Unlike `value`, altering `defaultValue` after the
`input` element has been added to the DOM has no effect.

values.name: defer
values.comment:
Indicates that a `script` should be executed after the page has been
parsed.

values.name: dir
values.comment:
Defines the text direction. Allowed values are ltr (Left-To-Right) or rtl
(Right-To-Left).

values.name: disabled
values.comment:
Indicates whether the user can interact with a `button`, `fieldset`,
`input`, `keygen`, `optgroup`, `option`, `select` or `textarea`.

values.name: download
values.comment:
Indicates that clicking an `a` and `area` will download the resource
directly.

values.name: downloadAs
values.comment:
Indicates that clicking an `a` and `area` will download the resource
directly, and that the downloaded resource with have the given filename.

values.name: draggable
values.comment: Defines whether the element can be dragged.

values.name: dropzone
values.comment: Indicates that the element accept the dropping of content on it.

values.name: enctype
values.comment:
How `form` data should be encoded when submitted with the POST method.
Options include: application/x-www-form-urlencoded, multipart/form-data, and
text/plain.

values.name: for
values.comment:
The element ID described by this `label` or the element IDs that are used
for an `output`.

values.name: form
values.comment:
Indicates the element ID of the `form` that owns this particular `button`,
`fieldset`, `input`, `keygen`, `label`, `meter`, `object`, `output`,
`progress`, `select`, or `textarea`.

values.name: formaction
values.comment:
Indicates the action of an `input` or `button`. This overrides the action
defined in the surrounding `form`.

values.name: headers
values.comment:
A space separated list of element IDs indicating which `th` elements are
headers for this cell. For `td` and `th`.

values.name: hidden
values.comment: Remove the element from the view.

values.name: href
values.comment: The URL of a linked resource, such as `a`, `area`, `base`, or `link`.

values.name: hreflang
values.comment: Two-letter language code of the linked resource of an `a`, `area`, or `link`.

values.name: httpEquiv
values.comment:
This attribute is an indicator that is paired with the `content` attribute,
indicating what that content means. `httpEquiv` can take on three different
values: content-type, default-style, or refresh. For `meta`.

values.name: id
values.comment:
Often used with CSS to style a specific element. The value of this
attribute must be unique.

values.name: inlineStyle
values.comment:
Specify a list of styles.

    myStyle : Attribute msg
    myStyle =
        style
            [ ( "backgroundColor", "red" )
            , ( "height", "90px" )
            , ( "width", "100%" )
            ]

    greeting : Html msg
    greeting =
        div [ myStyle ] [ text "Hello!" ]

There is no `Html.Styles` module because best practices for working with HTML
suggest that this should primarily be specified in CSS files. So the general
recommendation is to use this function lightly.
values.type: List ( String, String ) -> Element.Internal.Model.Attribute variation msg

values.name: ismap
values.comment:
When an `img` is a descendent of an `a` tag, the `ismap` attribute
indicates that the click location should be added to the parent `a`'s href as
a query string.

values.name: keytype
values.comment:
Specifies the type of key generated by a `keygen`. Possible values are:
rsa, dsa, and ec.

values.name: kind
values.comment: Specifies the kind of text `track`.

values.name: lang
values.comment: Defines the language used in the element.

values.name: language
values.comment: Defines the script language used in a `script`.

values.name: list
values.comment:
Associates an `input` with a `datalist` tag. The datalist gives some
pre-defined options to suggest to the user as they interact with an input.
The value of the list attribute must match the id of a `datalist` node.
For `input`.

values.name: loop
values.comment:
Indicates whether the `audio` or `video` should start playing from the
start when it's finished.

values.name: manifest
values.comment: Specifies the URL of the cache manifest for an `html` tag.

values.name: map
values.comment: Transform the messages produced by an `Attribute`.
values.type: (a -> msg) -> Element.Internal.Model.Attribute variation a -> Element.Internal.Model.Attribute variation msg

values.name: max
values.comment:
Indicates the maximum value allowed. When using an input of type number or
date, the max value must be a number or date. For `input`, `meter`, and `progress`.

values.name: maxlength
values.comment:
Defines the maximum number of characters allowed in an `input` or
`textarea`.

values.name: media
values.comment:
Specifies a hint of the target media of a `a`, `area`, `link`, `source`,
or `style`.

values.name: method
values.comment:
Defines which HTTP method to use when submitting a `form`. Can be GET
(default) or POST.

values.name: min
values.comment:
Indicates the minimum value allowed. When using an input of type number or
date, the min value must be a number or date. For `input` and `meter`.

values.name: minlength
values.comment:
Defines the minimum number of characters allowed in an `input` or
`textarea`.

values.name: moveXY
values.comment: Adjust the position of the element.

values.name: multiple
values.comment:
Indicates whether multiple values can be entered in an `input` of type
email or file. Can also indicate that you can `select` many options.

values.name: name
values.comment:
Name of the element. For example used by the server to identify the fields
in form submits. For `button`, `form`, `fieldset`, `iframe`, `input`, `keygen`,
`object`, `output`, `select`, `textarea`, `map`, `meta`, and `param`.

values.name: novalidate
values.comment:
This attribute indicates that a `form` shouldn't be validated when
submitted.

values.name: paddingXY
values.comment: Set horizontal and vertical padding.

values.name: pattern
values.comment:
Defines a regular expression which an `input`'s value will be validated
against.

values.name: ping
values.comment:
Specify a URL to send a short POST request to when the user clicks on an
`a` or `area`. Useful for monitoring and tracking.

values.name: placeholder
values.comment:
Provides a hint to the user of what can be entered into an `input` or
`textarea`.

values.name: poster
values.comment:
A URL indicating a poster frame to show until the user plays or seeks the
`video`.

values.name: preload
values.comment: Control how much of an `audio` or `video` resource should be preloaded.

values.name: property
values.comment:
Create *properties*, like saying `domNode.className = 'greeting'` in
JavaScript.

    import Json.Encode as Encode

    class : String -> Attribute variation msg
    class =
        Html.Attributes.class

Read more about the difference between properties and attributes [here].

[here]: https://github.com/elm-lang/html/blob/master/properties-vs-attributes.md

values.name: pubdate
values.comment:
Indicates whether this date and time is the date of the nearest `article`
ancestor element. For `time`.

values.name: readonly
values.comment: Indicates whether an `input` or `textarea` can be edited.

values.name: rel
values.comment:
Specifies the relationship of the target object to the link object.
For `a`, `area`, `link`.

values.name: required
values.comment:
Indicates whether this element is required to fill out or not.
For `input`, `select`, and `textarea`.

values.name: reversed
values.comment:
Indicates whether an ordered list `ol` should be displayed in a descending
order instead of a ascending.

values.name: rows
values.comment: Defines the number of rows in a `textarea`.

values.name: rowspan
values.comment:
Defines the number of rows a table cell should span over.
For `td` and `th`.

values.name: sandbox
values.comment:
A space separated list of security restrictions you'd like to lift for an
`iframe`.

values.name: scope
values.comment:
Specifies the scope of a header cell `th`. Possible values are: col, row,
colgroup, rowgroup.

values.name: scoped
values.comment:
Indicates that a `style` should only apply to its parent and all of the
parents children.

values.name: scrollbars
values.comment: Turn on scrollbars if content overflows.

values.name: seamless
values.comment: Make an `iframe` look like part of the containing document.

values.name: selected
values.comment: Defines which `option` will be selected on page load.

values.name: shape
values.comment:
Declare the shape of the clickable area in an `a` or `area`. Valid values
include: default, rect, circle, poly. This attribute can be paired with
`coords` to create more particular shapes.

values.name: size
values.comment:
For `input` specifies the width of an input in characters.

For `select` specifies the number of visible options in a drop-down list.

values.name: spacing
values.comment: Set the spacing between children in a layout.

values.name: spacingXY
values.comment:
Set the horizontal and vertical spacing separately.

This is generally only useful in a textLayout or a grid.

values.name: spellcheck
values.comment: Indicates whether spell checking is allowed for the element.

values.name: src
values.comment:
The URL of the embeddable content. For `audio`, `embed`, `iframe`, `img`,
`input`, `script`, `source`, `track`, and `video`.

values.name: srcdoc
values.comment:
An HTML document that will be displayed as the body of an `iframe`. It will
override the content of the `src` attribute if it has been specified.

values.name: srclang
values.comment: A two letter language code indicating the language of the `track` text data.

values.name: start
values.comment:
Defines the first number of an ordered list if you want it to be something
besides 1.

values.name: step
values.comment:
Add a step size to an `input`. Use `step "any"` to allow any floating-point
number to be used in the input.

values.name: tabindex
values.comment:
Overrides the browser's default tab order and follows the one specified
instead.

values.name: target
values.comment:
Specify where the results of clicking an `a`, `area`, `base`, or `form`
should appear. Possible special values include:

  - _blank — a new window or tab
  - _self — the same frame (this is default)
  - _parent — the parent frame
  - _top — the full body of the window

You can also give the name of any `frame` you have created.

values.name: title
values.comment: Text to be displayed in a tooltip when hovering over the element.

values.name: toAttr
values.comment:
Convert an existing `Html.Attribute` to an `Element.Attribute`.

This is useful for working with any library that returns a `Html.Attribute`.

values.name: type_
values.comment:
Defines the type of a `button`, `input`, `embed`, `object`, `script`,
`source`, `style`, or `menu`.

values.name: usemap
values.comment:
Specify the hash name reference of a `map` that should be used for an `img`
or `object`. A hash name reference is a hash symbol followed by the element's name or id.
E.g. `"#planet-map"`.

values.name: value
values.comment:
Defines a default value which will be displayed in a `button`, `option`,
`input`, `li`, `meter`, `progress`, or `param`.

values.name: vary
values.comment:
Apply a style variation.

    el MyButton [ vary Disabled True ] (text "My Disabled Button!")

values.name: wrap
values.comment:
Indicates whether the text should be wrapped in a `textarea`. Possible
values are "hard" and "soft".

values.name: xScrollbar
values.comment: Turn on scrollbars if content overflows horizontally.

values.name: yScrollbar
values.comment: Turn on scrollbars if content overflows vertically.

name: Style.Sheet
comment:
Combine and mix child stylesheets.

@docs ChildSheet, merge, map, mix

values.name: map
values.type: (class -> parent) -> (variation -> parentVariation) -> List (Style.Style class variation) -> Style.Sheet.ChildSheet parent parentVariation

values.name: merge
values.comment: Merge a child stylesheet into a parent.
values.type: Style.Sheet.ChildSheet class variation -> Style.Style class variation

values.name: mix
values.type: List (Style.Style class variation) -> Style.Style class variation

name: Style.Border

values.name: none
values.comment: No Borders

values.name: rounded
values.comment: Round all corners.

name: Style.Shadow

values.name: box
values.type: { offset : ( Float, Float ) , size : Float , blur : Float , color : Color.Color } -> Style.Shadow

values.name: deep
values.comment: A nice preset box shadow that's deeper than `simple`.

values.name: drop
values.type: { offset : ( Float, Float ), blur : Float, color : Color.Color } -> Style.Shadow

values.name: glow
values.comment: A simple glow by specifying the color and size.

values.name: inset
values.type: { offset : ( Float, Float ) , size : Float , blur : Float , color : Color.Color } -> Style.Shadow

values.name: simple
values.comment: A nice preset box shadow.

values.name: text
values.type: { offset : ( Float, Float ), blur : Float, color : Color.Color } -> Style.Shadow

name: Style.Filter
Style.Background

values.name: gradient
values.comment:
Here's an example of creating a background gradient:

    Background.gradient 0 [ step Color.blue, step Color.green]

The first number of the gradient angle given in radians, where 0 is pointing up.
values.type: Float -> List Style.Background.GradientStep -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: imageWith
values.type: { src : String , position : ( Float, Float ) , repeat : Style.Background.Repeat } -> Style.Property class variation

aliases.name: Transition
aliases.type: { delay : Time.Time , duration : Time.Time , easing : String , props : List String }

values.name: all
values.comment:
Sets transitions on all properties.

It defaults to:

    - 130ms duration
    - "ease" easing.

values.name: performant
values.comment:
This enables transitions on properties that will be GPU accelerated: `transform`, `filter`, and `opacity`.

It defaults to:

    - 130ms duration
    - "ease" easing.

values.name: transitions
values.comment: Create a set of transitions manually.

name: Style
comment:
# The Style part of the Style Elements Library!

Here is where you an create your style sheet.

One of the first concepts of `style-elements` is that layout, position, and width/height all live in your view through the `Element` module.

Your style sheet handles everything else!

Check out the other `Style` modules for other properties.

Check out `Basic.elm` in the examples folder to see an example of a full style sheet.


## The Basics

`style-elements` does away with CSS selectors entirely. Every style gets one identifier, which is ultimately rendered as a `class`.

@docs Style, style

Here's a basic example of a style that sets a few colors.

    import Style exposing (..)
    import Style.Color as Color
    import Color exposing (..)

    type Styles
        = Button

    stylesheet =
        Style.styleSheet
            [ style Button
                [ Color.background blue
                , Color.text white
                ]
            ]
    -- Which can be used in your view as:
    el Button [ ] (text "A button!")

@docs variation

Styles can have variations. Here's what it looks like to have a button style with a variation for `Disabled`

    import Style exposing (..)
    import Style.Color as Color
    import Color exposing (..)

    type Styles = Button

    -- You need to create a new type to capture vartiations.
    type Variations
            = Large


    stylesheet =
        Style.styleSheet
            [ style Button
                [ Font.size 16
                , variation Large
                    [ Font.size 20
                    ]
                ]
            ]

    -- which can be rendered in your view as

    el Button [ vary Disabled True ] (text "A Disabled button!")

Before you reach for a variation, consider just creating a subtype. So, something like:

    import Style exposing (..)
    import Style.Color as Color
    import Color exposing (..)

    type Styles
        = Button ButtonStyles

    type ButtonStyles
        = Active
        | Disabled


    stylesheet =
        Style.stylesheet
            [ style (Button Active)
                [ Color.background blue
                ]
            , style (Button Disabled)
                [ Color.background grey
                ]
            ]

    -- which can be rendered in your view as

    el (Button Active) [] (text "An Active button!")

The main difference between these two is that `variations` can combine with other `variations`, while subtypes are mutually exclusive.


## Properties

@docs Property, prop, opacity, cursor, paddingHint, paddingLeftHint, paddingRightHint, paddingTopHint, paddingBottomHint


## Shadows

Check out the `Style.Shadow` module for more about shadows.

@docs Shadow, shadows


## Filters

Check out the `Style.Filter` module for more about filters.

@docs Filter, filters


## Transformations

@docs origin, translate, rotate, rotateAround, scale


## Pseudo Classes

Psuedo classes can be nested.

@docs hover, checked, focus, pseudo


## Render into a Style Sheet

@docs StyleSheet, styleSheet, styleSheetWith, Option, unguarded, importUrl, importCss


## Deprecated

@docs stylesheet, stylesheetWith

values.name: checked
values.type: List (Style.Property class variation) -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: filters
focus
values.type: List (Style.Property class variation) -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: hover
values.comment:
Example:

    style Button
        [ Color.background blue
        , hover
            [ Color.background red
            ]
        ]
values.type: List (Style.Property class variation) -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: origin
values.comment: Set the transform origin.
values.type: Float -> Float -> Float -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: paddingHint
values.comment: You can give a hint about what the padding should be for this element, but the layout can override it.

values.name: pseudo
values.type: String -> List (Style.Property class variation) -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: rotate
values.comment:
Units always rendered as `radians`.

Use `degrees` or `turns` from the standard library if you want to use a different set of units.

values.name: rotateAround
values.comment:
Rotate around a vector.

Angle units always rendered as `radians`.

Use `degrees` or `turns` from the standard library if you want to use a different set of units.
values.type: ( Float, Float, Float ) -> Float -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: scale
values.type: Float -> Float -> Float -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: style
values.type: class -> List (Style.Property class variation) -> Style.Style class variation

values.name: styleSheet
values.type: List (Style.Style elem variation) -> Style.StyleSheet elem variation

values.name: styleSheetWith
values.type: List Style.Option -> List (Style.Style elem variation) -> Style.StyleSheet elem variation

values.name: stylesheet
values.comment: DEPRECATED, use styleSheet. This will be removed in the next major version
values.type: List (Style.Style elem variation) -> Style.StyleSheet elem variation

values.name: stylesheetWith
values.comment: DEPRECATED, use styleSheetWith. This will be removed in the next major version
values.type: List Style.Option -> List (Style.Style elem variation) -> Style.StyleSheet elem variation

values.name: translate
values.comment: Units are always as pixels
values.type: Float -> Float -> Float -> Style.Property class variation

values.name: unguarded
values.comment: Remove style hash guards from style classes.

values.name: variation
values.type: variation -> List (Style.Property class Basics.Never) -> Style.Property class variation

name: Style.Scale
comment:
When designing it's nice to use a modular scale to set spacial rythms.

    scaled =
        Scale.modular 16 1.618

A modular scale starts with a number, and multiplies it by a ratio a number of times.

Then, when setting font sizes you can use:

    Font.size (scaled 1) -- results in 16

    Font.size (scaled 2) -- 16 * (1.618 ^ 2) results in 25.8

We can also provide negative numbers to scale below 16px.

@docs modular, roundedModular

values.name: roundedModular
values.comment:
Same a modular but rounds to the nearest integer.

Still returns a Float for compatibility reasons.

name: Element.Events

aliases.name: Options
aliases.comment:
Options for an event listener. If `stopPropagation` is true, it means the
event stops traveling through the DOM so it will not trigger any other event
listeners. If `preventDefault` is true, any built-in browser behavior related
to the event is prevented. For example, this is used with touch events when you
want to treat them as gestures of your own, not as scrolls.

values.name: defaultOptions
values.comment:
Everything is `False` by default.

    defaultOptions =
        { stopPropagation = False
        , preventDefault = False
        }

values.name: keyCode
values.comment:
A `Json.Decoder` for grabbing `event.keyCode`. This helps you define
keyboard listeners like this:

    import Json.Decode as Json

    onKeyUp : (Int -> msg) -> Attribute msg
    onKeyUp tagger =
        on "keyup" (Json.map tagger keyCode)

**Note:** It looks like the spec is moving away from `event.keyCode` and
towards `event.key`. Once this is supported in more browsers, we may add
helpers here for `onKeyUp`, `onKeyDown`, `onKeyPress`, etc.

values.name: on
values.comment:
Create a custom event listener. Normally this will not be necessary, but
you have the power! Here is how `onClick` is defined for example:

    import Json.Decode as Json

    onClick : msg -> Attribute variation msg
    onClick message =
        on "click" (Json.succeed message)

The first argument is the event name in the same format as with JavaScript's
[`addEventListener`][aEL] function.
The second argument is a JSON decoder. Read more about these [here][decoder].
When an event occurs, the decoder tries to turn the event object into an Elm
value. If successful, the value is routed to your `update` function. In the
case of `onClick` we always just succeed with the given `message`.
If this is confusing, work through the [Elm Architecture Tutorial][tutorial].
It really does help!
[aEL]: <https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener>
[decoder]: <http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/elm-lang/core/latest/Json-Decode>
[tutorial]: <https://github.com/evancz/elm-architecture-tutorial/>
values.type: String -> Json.Decode.Decoder msg -> Element.Internal.Model.Attribute variation msg

values.name: onCheck
values.comment:
Capture [change](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/change)
events on checkboxes. It will grab the boolean value from `event.target.checked`
on any input event.
Check out [targetChecked](#targetChecked) for more details on how this works.

values.name: onInput
values.comment:
Capture [input](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/input)
events for things like text fields or text areas.
It grabs the **string** value at `event.target.value`, so it will not work if
you need some other type of information. For example, if you want to track
inputs on a range slider, make a custom handler with [`on`](#on).
For more details on how `onInput` works, check out [targetValue](#targetValue).

values.name: onSubmit
values.comment:
Capture a [submit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Events/submit)
event with [`preventDefault`](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/preventDefault)
in order to prevent the form from changing the pages location. If you need
different behavior, use `onWithOptions` to create a customized version of
`onSubmit`.

values.name: onWithOptions
values.comment: Same as `on` but you can set a few options.
values.type: String -> Html.Events.Options -> Json.Decode.Decoder msg -> Element.Internal.Model.Attribute variation msg

values.name: targetChecked
values.comment:
A `Json.Decoder` for grabbing `event.target.checked`. We use this to define
`onCheck` as follows:

    import Json.Decode as Json

    onCheck : (Bool -> msg) -> Attribute msg
    onCheck tagger =
        on "input" (Json.map tagger targetChecked)

values.name: targetValue
values.comment:
A `Json.Decoder` for grabbing `event.target.value`. We use this to define
`onInput` as follows:

    import Json.Decode as Json

    onInput : (String -> msg) -> Attribute msg
    onInput tagger =
        on "input" (Json.map tagger targetValue)

You probably will never need this, but hopefully it gives some insights into
how to make custom event handlers.
